content:
UK

UK PM May told Austria's PM Kurz 95% of the withdrawal deal is complete and she is confident a solution can be found on the NI backstop, while there were separate reports that UK is said to be aiming for a late November Brexit summit. (Newswires)

A senior EU official said there will be no breakthrough on the backstop this week and stated If there is no agreement in the next week at technical and services level, there’s no chance of a summit in November, according to RTE Europe Editor Connelly. However, Guardian's Brussels correspondent Rankin stated that an EU source told her a November summit is still possible. (Newswires)

ITV's Political Editor Peston tweeted "The UK government has decided that unless there is a Brexit deal within a week, the default option of a no-deal Brexit becomes the probable outcome, which is why officials are working through the night". (Twitter)

UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI (Oct) 52.2 vs. Exp. 53.3 (Prev. 53.9). (Newswires)


EU

Euro zone finance ministers have urged Italy's Finance Minister Tria to change the budget plan in a closed-door meeting, according to EU sources. Furthermore, Euro zone finance ministers agreed with European Commission that the Italian budget breaks EU rules according to a statement. (Newswires)

Italy Finance Minister Tria signalled to euro zone ministers he was working for compromise on the budget with the EU, while Tria stated the Italian 2019 draft budget won't change but debt will fall. (Newswires)

ECB policymakers are keen to avoid market disruption with the switch to the new capital key according to five sources, while a source sees the new capital key applying only to new asset purchases and another sees it gradually applied to stock of bonds. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

US President Trump said he wants to go slower on Iranian sanctions and does not want to raise oil prices, while US Secretary of State Pompeo said China, India, Italy, Greece, South Korea, Japan, Turkey and Taiwan have been granted temporary waivers from Iranian oil sanctions. (Newswires)


US

US Markit Comp Final PMI Oct 54.9 (Prev. 54.8)
 

MARKET RECAP

Energy names made gains today following the initial rally in oil with stocks such as Chevron (CVX), Apache (APA) and Halliburton (HAL) all trading higher. Berkshire Hathaway (BRKb) surged after reporting its quarterly profit doubling as well as a share repurchase programme. Under Armour (UAA) was a top mover following an upgrade at Piper Jaffray. Big tech names took a hit today with Apple (AAPL) sliding lower after a report of slowing demand and production for its iPhone XR. Wider pessimism in FAANG stocks brought down Amazon (AMZN), Facebook (FB) and Alphabet (GOOGL), which were also pressured by comments from US President Trump over the weekend who said he was looking into whether the companies have violated antitrust laws. Sysco (SYY) was also in the red on the back of reporting EPS and revenue below estimates. Video game heavyweight Activision Blizzard (ATVI) also traded lower on the day; this comes after a poorly received announcement of a mobile game this weekend amidst the broad tech weakness and ahead of their earnings report on Thursday. SPX +0.56% at 2738, NDX -0.40% at 6937, DJI +0.76% at 25461.

Treasuries were only marginally higher on Monday as investors were cautious ahead of the mid-term elections tomorrow and ahead of the FOMC rate decision due on Thursday. The yield curve saw some modest bull-flattening with yields on the short-end of the curve pivoting around the unchanged mark whilst longer dated yields were lower by c.2bps at settlement. 2s30s narrowed by c.3bps and 2s10s by c.2bps.The US treasury sold USD 37bln in 3yr notes tailing by 0.3bps at a high yield of 2.983%. Demand was soft as the bid-to-cover came in at 2.54x, well below recent averages and the lowest since July. Directs took the smallest portion since December 2009, indirects were awarded the biggest share since June whilst dealers were left with the largest share since July. US T-note futures (Z8) settled at 118-05+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 5th November 2018 - Tech stocks tumble; Trump chatter clears crude climb
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

 

  • SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries flat/down, dollar flat, crude down.
  • REAR-VIEW: US announces list of countries temporary exempted from Iran sanctions, Trump doesn’t want to drive up oil prices, UK unlikely to see deal this week, Moscovici dismisses disciplining on Italy, US ISM non-mfg (final) beat.
  • AHEAD: US Mid-Term Elections, Australian RBA Cash Rate, Eurozone Final PMIs, New Zealand Labour Market Data, ECB's Praet, Lautenschlager, Coeure, de Guindos and Praet to Speak, UK Cabinet Meeting on Brexit.

* BREXIT: On Monday, focus fell on the timing of a Brexit deal with sources suggesting that unless an agreement is achieved by the end of the week, a no-deal Brexit is most probable. Whitehall sources appeared sceptical about a breakthrough in negotiations at the end of this week and therefore pushed the prospective date for a deal to November 27th-28th. There were also reports that the UK is aiming for a late November Brexit summit with BBC Laura Kuenssberg citing November 26th /27th as potential dates. With regards to negotiations, Irish PM Varadkar and PM May held a phone call where both leaders emphasized their commitment to avoid a hard border and the need for a legally operable backstop; Varadkar also said PM May raised the possibility of a review mechanism for backstop over which he would be open to consider proposals. Nonetheless, UK PM May’s spokesman noted there are outstanding and significant issues relating to the Irish backstop and work is ongoing to resolve them and, similarly, an EU Commission spokesman stated technical works continue in order to reach a Brexit deal, but that they are not there yet. Looking ahead, May will host a cabinet meeting on Tuesday and will reportedly tell ministers that failure to support her plans with make dissenters responsible for a no-deal Brexit. In later comments, UK PM May told Austria's PM Kurz 95% of the withdrawal deal is complete and she is confident a solution can be found on the NI backstop.

* ITALY: Italy’s approach to its budget plan continued to face EU criticism; reports in Politico suggested the EU Commission is to propose disciplining Italy on November 21st unless the region amends its budget plan, an assertion later dismissed by European Commissioner Moscovici who stated sanctions on Italy are “fake news”. Moscovici went on to say that he has not yet made up his mind on whether to start disciplinary steps. In related comments, Eurogroup Head Centeno said the Eurogroup will not take any decisions on the country but hopes Italy bring the budget in-line with rules, whilst EU's Dombrovskis reiterated once again that the fiscal plan needs substantial adjustments and that the country is openly not acting in line with EU rules. Later in the day, EU sources reported that Eurozone finance ministers have urged Italy's Economy Minister Tria to change the budget plan in a closed-door meeting and have agreed with the European Commission that the Italian budget breaks EU rules.

* TRADE: EU's Dombrovskis said that EU trade talks continue with the US but there is no deadline.

* ECB: ECB's Smets (Dove) said low rates are necessary to help the European area recovery adding that he expects further expansion in the Euro area. Elsewhere, five sources reported that ECB policymakers are keen to avoid market disruption with the switch to the new capital key; one source sees the new capital key applying only to new asset purchases, and another sees it gradually applied to stock of bonds. The ECB's "operation twist" runs into constraints in some countries.

* ISM NON-MANUFACTURING INDEX came in at 60.3 for October, beating the expected figure of 59.3 and slightly lower than September’s 61.6. Wells Fargo notes that this figure, coming off a 21-year high from September, still signals a “robust” pace of activity, and that a tight supply chain from increasing backlogs of orders and supplier delivery times suggests continued inflationary pressures. Looking into the sub-components: business activity fell by 2.7 points to 62.5, cooler than the expected 64.5; new orders recorded 61.5, essentially flat from September’s 61.5; employment index read 59.7, down 2.7 points from September but still strong and in line with the solid payrolls number on Friday.

* SPX +0.56% at 2738, NDX -0.40% at 6937, DJI +0.76% at 25461. SECTORS: Energy +1.61%, Materials +0.38%, Industrials +0.53%, Cons Discretionary -0.18%, Cons Staples +1.21%, Healthcare +0.84%, Financials +1.40%, Tech -0.18%, Telecoms -0.31%, Utilities +1.39%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Energy names made gains today following the rally in oil with stocks such as Chevron (CVX), Apache (APA) and Halliburton (HAL) all trading higher. Berkshire Hathaway (BRKb) surged after reporting its quarterly profit doubling as well as a share repurchase programme. Under Armour (UAA) was a top mover following an upgrade at Piper Jaffray. Big tech names took a hit today with Apple (AAPL) sliding lower after a report of slowing demand and production for its iPhone XR. Wider pessimism in FAANG stocks brought down Amazon (AMZN), Facebook (FB) and Alphabet (GOOGL), which were also pressured by comments from US President Trump over the weekend who said he was looking into whether the companies have violated antitrust laws. Sysco (SYY) was also in the red on the back of reporting EPS and revenue below estimates. Video game heavyweight Activision Blizzard (ATVI) also traded lower on the day; this comes after a poorly received announcement of a mobile game this weekend amidst the broad tech weakness and ahead of their earnings report on Thursday.

* WTI (Z8) SETTLES USD 0.04 LOWER AT USD 63.10/BBL, BRENT (F9) SETTLES USD 0.34 HIGHER AT USD 73.17/BBL. Oil prices closed in the red on Monday as markets digested the new Iranian sanctions imposed by the US. US Secretary of State Pompeo said more than 20 countries have already cut oil imports from Iran, reducing purchases by more than 1mln bpd. Although gains were restricted, partly due to the US confirming the eight countries it would temporarily waver the sanctions on: China, India, Greece, Italy, Taiwan, Japan, Turkey and South Korea; some of these are Iran’s top importers. Trump later added that he wants to go slow on the tariffs and does not want to drive up world oil prices which contributed to a reversal in previous gains. Iran also threw wood on the fire by saying it would break away from the sanctions and continue exporting oil; it later announced it had other channels planned for trade with partners. This week’s API are seeing headline crude +2.1mln, distillates -2.8mln, gasoline -2.6mln and cushing +36k.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLES TICKS HIGHER AT 118-05+. Treasuries were only marginally higher on Monday as investors were cautious ahead of the mid-term elections tomorrow and ahead of the FOMC rate decision due on Thursday. The yield curve saw some modest bull-flattening with yields on the short-end of the curve pivoting around the unchanged mark whilst longer dated yields were lower by c.2bps at settlement. 2s30s narrowed by c.3bps and 2s10s by c.2bps.The US treasury sold USD 37bln in 3yr notes tailing by 0.3bps at a high yield of 2.983%. Demand was soft as the bid-to-cover came in at 2.54x, well below recent averages and  the lowest since July. Directs took the smallest portion since December 2009, indirects were awarded the biggest share since June whilst dealers were left with the largest share since July.

* GBP: Cable and the Pound in general has been relatively (remarkably?) resilient in the face of reports that the UK Government has imposed a 1 week deadline to resolve the remaining and key issues on Brexit with the EU before resorting to default no deal mode, ahead of Tuesday’s Cabinet meeting that could be crucial for PM May. Moreover, reports suggest that Brexit Minister Raab may resign if she agrees to an indefinite back-stop on the Irish border and all UK customs union, while the macro backdrop turns decidedly downbeat vs last Thursday’s improved BoE assessment as the services PMI weakened more than expected and IHS Markit projected tepid 0.2% q/q growth for the 3 months ending October vs forecast for 0.6% Q3 GDP. However, Cable rebounded from sub-1.3000 again and Eur/Gbp held around 0.8750 as the single currency suffered more Italian fiscal jitters – more to on this come later.

* NZD, CAD, AUD: The Kiwi maintained its recovery momentum from overnight lows and a disappointing NZ Treasury survey to nudge up towards 0.6670 whilst the Loonie  extended its comeback from circa 1.3110 to 1.3070 on the back of hawkish-sounding comments from BoC’s Poloz (current pace of policy normalisation just right, but pace of hikes rise or fall depending on data) before USD weakness pushed the pair back towards 1.3100.  Meanwhile, the Aud lagged, though did just reclaim 0.7200+ status amidst ongoing US-China trade uncertainty and eyeing the RBA overnight for some independent impetus – check out the Research Suite for a full preview.

* EUR, JPY, CHF: Narrowly mixed vs the Greenback even though the DXY slipped a bit further from post-NFP peaks to trade back below 96.400, with the single currency back on 1.1400+ levels on more Italy vs EU budget angst and USD weakness, while the Jpy bounced above 113.00, albeit also supported ahead of 113.50 having absorbed option-related supply at 113.25 before the NY cut and the Franc rebounded from moderately deeper lows close to 1.0070 to revisit resistance near 1.0020.

* EM: A solid start to the week for most if not all regional currencies, benefiting from the aforementioned Dollar downturn (pre-midterm elections and FOMC) and for the Lira also welcoming the US exemption from Iranian sanctions – Usd/Try through 5.4000 and at fresh multi-month lows. Usd/Zar also trending lower again and now under 14.2000, while Usd/Mxn retested bids under 20.0000.

* COMING-UP:

* PREVIEW: RBA rate decision due on Tuesday 6th November at 0330GMT/2130CST/1130HKT. The RBA are to announce its latest policy decision on Tuesday in which the central bank is unanimously expected to keep rates on hold at the record low 1.5% where they have been for more than 2 years, while the board is highly anticipated to retain its view of no strong case for a near-term rate move and that the next move is likely to be upwards. These expectations have been reflected through ASX 30-Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures which price in 100% expectations of no change in the Cash Rate Target, while its implied yield curve suggests February 2020 as the earliest date for when the curve is leaning more towards a hike. Click here to access the full RANsquawk preview.

* PREVIEW: US midterm elections (6 November 2018). Voting to take place Tuesday on 6 November, with polls closing at 8pm local time(s). The base case is for Republicans to retain the Senate, while Democrats are seen winning the House. Democrats taking the House could be a 'market-unfriendly' scenario. Key issues for markets are Tax Reform 2.0 and Trade policy. Click here to access the full RANsquawk preview.

  • Apple (AAPL) – Nikkei reports that the tech giant has cancelled plans for an iPhone XR production boost following disappointing demand
  • Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A, BRK.B) Q3 operating earnings USD 6.88bln vs. Prev. USD 3.44bln. Announces repurchase of USD 928mln in Q3
  • UNDER ARMOUR (UAA) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT PIPER JAFFRAY

5th November 2018

Earnings

  • Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A, BRK.B) Q3 operating earnings USD 6.88bln vs. Prev. USD 3.44bln. Q3 net earnings of USD 18.5bln. At September 30th, book value per Class A equivalent share was USD 228,712. Announces repurchase of USD 928mln in Q3. (Newswires)
  • Ferrari (RACE IM) Q3 Adj. EBITDA EUR 278mln vs. Exp. EUR 204.1mln (Prev. 266mln), revenue EUR 838mln vs. Exp EUR 871mln (Prev. 836mln); 2018 outlook confirmed. (Newswires)
  • Loews Corp (L) Q3 EPS USD 0.88 vs. Exp. USD 0.98, revenue USD 3.61bln vs. Exp. USD 4.28bln. (Newswires)
  • Sysco Corp (SYY) Q1 Adj. EPS USD 0.91 vs. Exp. USD 0.92, revenue USD 15.2bln vs. Exp. USD 15.4bln. (Newswires)
  • WestRock Co (WRK) Q3 EPS USD 1.29 vs. Exp. USD 1.24, revenue USD 4.24bln vs. Exp. USD 4.28bln. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – Nikkei reports that the tech giant has cancelled plans for an iPhone XR production boost following disappointing demand. Elsewhere, Fast Company reported that the co. will launch its first 5G iPhone in 2020, which will utilise Intel’s (INTC) 8161 5G modem chip. Elsewhere Apple filed for potential debt shelf; size was not disclosed according to a SEC filing. (Nikkei, Fast Company)
  • Boeing (BA) – Indonesian authorities have determined that the plane’s airspeed indicator had been damaged for the last four flights of the recent Lion Air crash, killing all 189 people on board the Boeing 737 MAX plane. (Newswires)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – The investment bank is set to name its smallest number of new partners since 1998, fewer than 65 people will be appointed. (WSJ)
  • Microsoft (MSFT) – The computer co.’s CEO Satya Nadella said that the co. does not utilise/exploit user data from its Bing search engine and Linkedin website to increase profits. (The Times)
  • Pfizer (PFE) – The pharma giant has received FDA approval for its lung cancer treating drug, Lorbrena. (Newswires)
  • Verizon (VZ) – The telecoms giant has made corporate restructuring in which it will focus on three customer-facing areas: Consumer, Business and Verizon Media Group / Oath. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • American Airlines (AAL) – The airline has signed a new contract with Embraer (ERJ) for 15 E175s which has a value of USD 705mln. (Newswires)
  • Bristol-Myers (BMY), Infinity Pharmaceuticals (INFI) – The two pharma co.s have collaborated to evaluate Bristol-Myers Squibb's Opdivo in combination with Infinity's IPI-549 for the treatment of advanced urothelial cancer. (Newswires)
  • Ecolab (ECL) – The water and energy group announced price increases for customers in all its segments, effective November 15th. (Newswires)
  • Eli Lilly (LLY) – The pharma co.’s study EMPRISE showed a 44% risk reduction in heart failure. Elsewhere, its REWIND trial for Trulicity met its primary endpoints where it reduced major adverse cardiovascular events; it plans to submit data to regulatory authorities next year. (Newswires)
  • F5 Networks (FFIV) – The web applications co. has announced an additional USD 1bln to the current USD 0.574mln share repurchase programme. (Newswires)
  • General Electric (GE) – The UK media said the UK is to disallow USD 1bln in tax deductions claimed by GE. Elsewhere, the co. will pay ousted CEO John Flannery USD 4.25mln in severance pay. CEO Larry Culp bought 225 shares in the co. (Newswires) 
  • Grainger (GWW) – The industrial supply co. has appointed Kathleen Carroll as its new senior VP and CHRO, who comes from the same position previously at First Midwest Bank (FMBI). (Newswires)
  • Lowe’s (LOW) – The home retail products group has announced it will be closing underperforming stores, 20 in the US and 31 in Canada, this is amidst its strategic reassessment; expected impact on fiscal 2018 EPS is expected to be USD 0.28-0.34.  (Newswires)
  • MGM Resorts (MGM), Caesars (CZR) – Resorts co. MGM has hired Morgan Stanley (MS) and the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges to begin exploring a potential merger with the other casino and resorts co. Caesars. (NY Post)
  • Roper Technologies (ROP) – The niche industrial products co.’s Executive Chairman and former CEO, Brian Jellison, passed away on Friday. (Newswires)
  • Sempra Energy (SRE) – The energy co., alongside Total (FP FP), have entered a Memorandum of Understanding for development of LNG export projects in North America. (Newswires)
  • Twitter (TWTR) – The social media co. has removed more than 10,000 accounts which were automated to discourage people from voting in Tuesday’s midterm elections. (Newswires)
  • Westrock (WRK) – The paper packaging co. has completed its acquisition of KapStone Paper and Packaging, it expects to achieve USD 200mln in synergies and performance improvements by the end of 2021. (Newswires)
  • Weyerhaeuser (WY), Union Pacific (UNP), Caterpillar (CAT) – The co.s have all said China tariffs have had impacts on their prices and supply chains, warning of more hits to their businesses in the future. (WSJ)
  • Barron’s writes that defence stocks have been oversold and how they are set to benefit from increased defence spending from the military; stocks named included Lockheed Martin (LMT), Northrop Grumman (NOC), and Raytheon (RTN). It mentioned how big tech is also set to gain from military spending as governments look to utilise their software for advanced weapons; stocks mentioned included Amazon (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT), and Alphabet (GOOGL). (Barron’s)
  • Barron’s writes that scepticism has soon mounted around IBM’s (IBM) USD 34bln acquisition of Red Hat (RHT) after contemplation of previous bad decisions made by IBM such as Watson healthcare products. (Barron’s)
  • Barron’s writes that the niche heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning group has potential to rally in the future, specifically stocks such as Ingersoll-Rand (IR) and Lennox International (LII). (Barron’s)
  • Barron’s writes that investors should start allocating towards stocks with minimal debt as interest rates begin to rise, mentioning retailers Gap (GPS) and Costco (COST), industrials including Southwest Airlines (LUV), and tech stocks such as Micron Technology (MU) and Alphabet (GOOGL). (Barron’s)
  • Barron’s writes that Honeywell’s (HON) new spinout of Resideo Technologies (REZI) is a “bargain” tech stock, potentially worth 45% greater than its current share price. (Barron’s)

NASDAQ

  • Activision Blizzard (ATVI) – The Blizzard unit announced its popular Diablo game will be coming to mobile phones with the assistance of NetEase (NTES), both iOS and Android, as well as announcing it will be making a relaunch of its real-time strategy game Warcraft III. (Newswires)
  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – More than 20,000 employees took part in the “walkout for real change” over 50 cities worldwide, the protest against sexual misconduct in the co. (Medium)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – The online retailer has begun free shipping to all its US customers for the holiday season. Elsewhere, Quartz reported that the co. is hiring 20,000 less workers than the previous year for the holiday season, with a Citi analyst indicating this could well be due to the co.’s move to automation. Recode reports that two contractors at an Amazon warehouse in Baltimore were killed from a falling wall in a storm. (Newswires, Quartz, Recode)
  • Amazon (AMZN), Facebook (FB), Google (GOOGL) – US President Trump took fire at big tech, speaking to Axios saying he is looking into whether the companies have violated antitrust laws, following the EU’s USD 5bln fine for the Google. (Axios)

OTHER NEWS

  • Sage Therapeutics (SAGE) – The pharma co. has received FDA advisory panel support for its postpartum depression treating injection, Zulresso. (Newswires)
  • Spotify (SPOT) – The music streaming co. has announced a USD 1bln share repurchase programme which will begin in Q4. (Newswires)
  • WPP (WPP) – The public relations co. has halted hiring amid faltering growth in the co., it had previously looked to hire an additional 2,000 workers. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

content:
•   USD up vs. all G10 but GBP; active traders remain very long; downside risk.

  •   EUR soft under 1.14 as market focus on rumors of new TLTROs; neutral.
  •   GBP outperforming on Brexit hopes however we remain cautious.
  •   JPY extends Friday’s bearish reversal & threatens fresh lows on dovish Kuroda.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 5th November 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities kick start the week mixed with the FTSE MIB weighed on by banks amid stress test results
  • The Times reported UK PM May secured private concessions from Brussels that will keep Britain in a customs union and avoid a hard border, this was later dismissed as speculation by Downing Street
  • Dollar has lost some of Friday’s post-NFP recovery momentum ahead of the US mid-term elections and FOMC, but the index is holding relatively firm around 96.500
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US ISM non-mfg PMI, EZ finance ministers to discuss Italy, ECB’s de Guindos, Praet, BoC’s Poloz, US Secretary of State Pompeo, EU’s Chief Negotiator Barnier and US 3yr Note Auction

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week with a negative tone after last Friday’s losses on Wall St where the Nasdaq underperformed after tech giant Apple dropped nearly 7%, while sentiment was also dampened by soft Chinese Caixin PMI data and after US-China trade hopes were tempered by pessimism from NEC’s Kudlow. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) were both pressured from the open although stocks in Australia briefly recovered in tandem with the price swings in its largest weighted financial sector as participants mulled over Westpac’s flat FY profits, while focus in Japan remained on corporate updates including index heavyweight Fast Retailing which slumped following a 10% decline in same-store sales. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-2.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were negative after US administration officials downplayed prospects of an imminent resolution to the US-China trade dispute and with Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMI at the weakest since September 2017 and June 2016 respectively, while the PBoC Medium-term Lending Facility announcement and President Xi’s pledge to further open up China’s economy only helped plug losses momentarily. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher as the risk averse tone spurred demand for safety. This helped prices recover from Friday’s declines which coincided with a sell-off in T-notes and a surge in US yields by the most in the month following the NFP-beat.

PBoC skipped open market operations but conducted CNY 403.5bln 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility vs. Prev. CNY 265bln with rates unchanged at 3.30%. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8976 (Prev. 6.9371)

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (Oct) 50.8 vs. Exp. 52.9 (Prev. 53.1); lowest since September 2017
Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Oct) 50.5 (Prev. 52.1); lowest since June 2016

Chinese President Xi said China pledges to open market to the world, while he added that countries must pursue open policy and oppose protectionism. Furthermore, President Xi stated that China will stimulate potential for increased imports and are to further reduce import tariffs. (Newswires)

BoJ minutes from September meeting stated that most members shared the view that the year-on-year rate of change in the CPI was likely to increase gradually toward 2% and that it is appropriate to continue easing persistently. Furthermore, the minutes noted that financial conditions are highly accommodative and that most members agreed momentum to target was intact. (Newswires)

BoJ Governor Kuroda said BoJ is aware continued loose policy impacts financial system stability and financial intermediation, while he added the BoJ must carefully watch demerits of easing and that large deflation policy is no longer the most appropriate. Kuroda also commented that when BoJ seeks to exit easy policy, the yield curve will steepen although that alone will not lift financial institutions out of structural problems, while he later reiterated there is no change in stance of reaching 2% target and that BoJ needs to continue easing persistently to the CPI target. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May secured private concessions from Brussels that will keep Britain in a customs union and avoid a hard border, while reports also noted Britain is on course for a future economic partnership deal with the EU. (Sunday Times) However, some sources noted that Downing Street had dismissed this as speculation. (Twitter) May will host a cabinet meeting on Tuesday and will reportedly tell ministers that failure to support her plans with make dissenters responsible for a no-deal Brexit. (Newswires)

UK Brexit Secretary Raab pressed UK PM May to take a hard line regarding Irish border and urged her to back plan to pull UK out of backstop plan at only 3-months’ notice. (Telegraph/FT)

Senior EU officials stated that UK PM May's chances of reaching an Irish border deal are '50-50' and that competing red lines between UK and EU continue to be incompatible in important areas. (Guardian)

Irish Foreign Minister Coveney tweeted "The Irish position remains consistent and v clear that a “time-limited backstop” or a backstop that could be ended by UK unilaterally would never be agreed to by IRE"; adding that “these ideas are not backstops at all, they don’t deliver on previous UK commitments”. (Twitter)

EU Commission spokesman says technical works continues in order to reach a Brexit deal; but we are not there yet. (Newswires)

UK PM May spokesman says Brexit talks are making good progress but there is still work to do; adding they do not want a backstop to be in place and are looking for a mechanism to deal with it. (Newswires)

BBC's Chief Political Editor Kuenssberg tweeted that talks still stuck on backstop mechanism, if there is to be a November summit there must be decisive process and Tusk won't press the button unless both sides are sure the makings of a deal are there (Twitter)

ITV's Political Editor Peston tweeted "The UK government has decided that unless there is a Brexit deal within a week, the default option of a no-deal Brexit becomes the probable outcome, which is why officials are working through the night", adding “The important dates are tomorrow, when the prime minister briefs her cabinet on the likely shape of a deal, and (probably) next Monday - which is the probable cut-off day for organising an emergency Brexit council of EU leaders.” The article also states that eyes re on UK Brexit Secretary Raab as “a few members of the Cabinet may prefer to resign than endorse what they would see as backstop”. (Twitter/Facebook)

RTE's Political Editor Connelly, after having spoken to various officials, tweeted "Dublin and the EU Task Force are still insisting on a Northern Ireland-specific backstop as a final safety net if the UK-wide customs arrangement doesn't work"

UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI (Oct) 52.2 vs. Exp. 53.3 (Prev. 53.9)
UK Composite PMI (Oct) M/M 52.1 vs. exp. 53.4 (Prev. 54.1)

Italian government are to call for a confidence vote in the upper house senate regarding the security bill, according to sources. (Newswires)

European Commission’s Vice President Dombrovskis reiterated that the Italian budget plan needs substantial adjustments. (Newswires)

US

Press reports speculate that any agreement reached between President Trump and Chinese President Xi is likely to be a temporary truce instead of a significant step forward. (Newswires)

European Commission’s Vice President Dombrovskis says that EU trade talks continue with the US but there is no deadline. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are mixed, with Spain’s IBEX 35 (+0.5%) leading the gains, and Italy’s FTSE MIB (-0.4%) lagging as the index is weighed on by local banking names such as Banco BPM (-2.5%) and Intesa Sanpaolo (-2.0%) as finance minister discuss Italy and amid the release of stress test results, which showed the former as the worst performing Italian lender following a slump in the nation’s bonds amid political turmoil. Furthermore, Barclays (-0.1%) and Lloyds Banking Group (-0.8%) were amongst the worst performers due to weak growth, credit losses and Brexit uncertainty.

Moving on, major sectors are mixed with utilities (+0.6%) and consumer staples (+0.6%) outperforming, while industrials are lagging (-0.5%).

In terms of individual equities, GAM (+2%) shares are in the green after being approached by Schroders (-1.6%) regarding a potential acquisition; which sources say GAM rejected. On the flip side, Hiscox (-7.3%) are lagging in the Stoxx 600, after their earnings showed a substantial increase in written premiums.

FX

USD - The broad Dollar has lost some of Friday’s post-NFP recovery momentum ahead of the US mid-term elections and FOMC, but the index is holding relatively firm around 96.500 as major pairings trade somewhat mixed.

GBP/NZD - Vying for top spot amongst G10 rivals, and perhaps surprisingly or unexpectedly as the Pound recovers from another UK PMI miss, and from the major services sector. However, Cable is back above 1.3000 from a knee-jerk dip to circa 1.2970 and still benefiting from latest press reports suggesting the EU has made concessions on the Irish border and customs front, albeit someway off high just over 1.3060 at one stage. Similarly, the Kiwi has rebounded firmly from overnight lows on the back of a pretty downbeat NZ Treasury business survey revealing a further deterioration in sentiment over Q3 and risks to the growth outlook for 2018 and next year due to global trade spats. Nzd/Usd back up around 0.6665 vs 0.6635 at worst, with cross-winds also helping as AUD/Nzd remains anchored near 1.0800 and Aud/Usd struggles to climb through 0.7200.

EUR/CAD/JPY/CHF - All underperforming vs the Greenback, with the single currency capped around 1.1400 and still wary about another Italy vs EU face-off on the budget, while the Loonie straddles 1.3100 after last Friday’s NA jobs data (Canadian not as upbeat as US, largely on soft wages) and ahead of a speech by BoC Governor Poloz. Usd/Jpy has nudged further beyond 113.00 and soaked up offers/hedges vs a modest 113.25 option expiry and the Franc is back under parity within a 1.0020-55 range.

EM - Regional currencies are broadly weaker vs the Usd with the Yuans undermined by less encouraging US-China trade vibes and weak Chinese PMIs, while the Try is pivoting 5.4500 in wake of Turkish inflation data showing a further rise in CPI.

COMMODITIES

WTI (-0.3%) and Brent (-0.1%) are just off session lows with choppy trade experienced in the complex following the implementation of oil-related sanctions on Iran by the US. Iranian President emerged stating that Iran will sell oil and break sanctions, while he added that Iran is open to talks with the US once President Trump respects commitments. Temporary exemptions are being granted to eight countries making the sanctions less severe than anticipated, additionally removing the risk of a supply shortage according some analysts. Furthermore, Iranian press noted that the terms of the Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) with the EU will be announced soon. The SPV is the European effort to process Iran’s import and export payments. Diplomats said the details are being discussed by finance ministers, with EU Finance Ministers due to meet in Brussels on Tuesday, although the SPV was not on the agenda as of Sunday.

Gold (+0.1%) is flat and off of session highs as the yellow metal mirrors USD moves. Elsewhere, copper prices pulled back on profit taking and amid the averse risk tone.

FIXED INCOME

Only a fleeting uptick in Gilts on the UK services PMI miss before a retest of pre-release Liffe lows and subsequent minor loss of Fib support to 121.60 (-24 ticks vs +8 ticks at best), as the FTSE regroups alongside other EU indices, and only partly on currency effect. In truth, trade is all very choppy with Bunds also back down near worst levels traded on Eurex having climbed to 159.91 (+28 ticks) when Italian bonds lost grip of the 122.00 handle, and the 10 year Eurozone benchmarks now somewhat decoupled. subject: ITV's Political Editor Peston tweeted "The UK government  has decided that unless there is a Brexit deal within a week, the default option of a no-deal Brexit becomes the probable outcome, which is why officials are working through the night"
content:
• The article goes on to say:

“We don’t want no-deal. But because of the parliamentary timetable it becomes very hard to avoid if talks continue past this month” said a senior member of the government. “And that is why negotiation have massively shifted up a gear, with officials working through the night”.

The important dates are tomorrow, when the prime minister briefs her cabinet on the likely shape of a deal, and (probably) next Monday - which is the probable cut-off day for organising an emergency Brexit council of EU leaders.

In the short term, the risk for May of Brexiters cutting up rough is that a few members of the Cabinet may prefer to resign than endorse what they would see as backstop (the UK as vassal state) in perpetuity - and most ministerial eyes are on the Brexiter Brexit secretary Dominic Raab, because he has been publicly posturing that the UK must have a unilateral right to terminate the backstop.

Click here for the link

subject: RTE's Political Editor, after having spoken to various officials, tweeted "Dublin and the EU Task Force are still insisting on a Northern Ireland-specific backstop as a final safety net if the UK-wide customs arrangement doesn't work"
content: He added: "One Irish source says: "There’s no question of subordinating or dissolving the NI backstop. It must be legally operable, and it must apply unless and until [something else comes along]. There’s absolutely no change in our position, there’s no change in the EU’s position."

subject: RANsquawk EU Mid Session: EU bourses flat. GBP lifted by Brexit optimism and domestic data - 5th November 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

Major European indices are mixed, with Spain’s IBEX 35 (+0.5%) leading the gains, and Italy’s FTSE MIB (-0.4%) lagging as the index is weighed on by local banking names such as Banco BPM (-2.5%) and Intesa Sanpaolo (-2.0%) following the release of stress test results, which showed the former as the worst performing Italian lender following a slump in the nation’s bonds amid political turmoil. Furthermore, Barclays (-0.1%) and Lloyds Banking Group (-0.8%) were amongst the worst performers due to weak growth, credit losses and Brexit uncertainty.

Moving on, major sectors are mixed with utilities (+0.6%) and consumer staples (+0.6%) outperforming, while industrials are lag (-0.5%).

In terms of individual equities, GAM (+2%) shares are in the green after being approached by Schroders (-1.6%) regarding a potential acquisition; which sources say GAM rejected. On the flip side, Hiscox (-7.3%) are lagging in the Stoxx 600, after their earnings showed a substantial increase in written premiums. 

FX

USD - The broad Dollar has lost some of Friday’s post-NFP recovery momentum ahead of the US mid-term elections and FOMC, but the index is holding relatively firm around 96.500 as major pairings trade somewhat mixed.

GBP/NZD - Vying for top spot amongst G10 rivals, and perhaps surprisingly or unexpectedly as the Pound recovers from another UK PMI miss, and from the major services sector. However, Cable is back above 1.3000 from a knee-jerk dip to circa 1.2970 and still benefiting from latest press reports suggesting the EU has made concessions on the Irish border and customs front, albeit someway off high just over 1.3060 at one stage. Similarly, the Kiwi has rebounded firmly from overnight lows on the back of a pretty downbeat NZ Treasury business survey revealing a further deterioration in sentiment over Q3 and risks to the growth outlook for 2018 and next year due to global trade spats. Nzd/Usd back up around 0.6665 vs 0.6635 at worst, with cross-winds also helping as AUD/Nzd remains anchored near 1.0800 and Aud/Usd struggles to climb through 0.7200.

EUR/CAD/JPY/CHF - All underperforming vs the Greenback, with the single currency capped around 1.1400 and still wary about another Italy vs EU face-off on the budget, while the Loonie straddles 1.3100 after last Friday’s NA jobs data (Canadian not as upbeat as US, largely on soft wages) and ahead of a speech by BoC Governor Poloz. Usd/Jpy has nudged further beyond 113.00 and soaked up offers/hedges vs a modest 113.25 option expiry and the Franc is back under parity within a 1.0020-55 range.

EM - Regional currencies are broadly weaker vs the Usd with the Yuans undermined by less encouraging US-China trade vibes and weak Chinese PMIs, while the Try is pivoting 5.4500 in wake of Turkish inflation data showing a further rise in CPI.

FIXED INCOME

Only a fleeting uptick in Gilts on the UK services PMI miss before a retest of pre-release Liffe lows and subsequent minor loss of Fib support to 121.60 (-24 ticks vs +8 ticks at best), as the FTSE regroups alongside other EU indices, and only partly on currency effect. In truth, trade is all very choppy with Bunds also back down near worst levels traded on Eurex having climbed to 159.91 (+28 ticks) when Italian bonds lost grip of the 122.00 handle, and the 10 year Eurozone benchmarks now somewhat decoupled. However, US Treasuries remain on a modestly firmer footing and rather oblivious ahead of a big week, with mid-term election, Fed and supply risk all impending.   

COMMODITIES

WTI (-0.3%) and Brent (-0.1%) are just off session lows with choppy trade experienced in the complex following the implementation of oil-related sanctions on Iran by the US. Iranian President emerged stating that Iran will sell oil and break sanctions, while he added that Iran is open to talks with the US once President Trump respects commitments. Temporary exemptions are being granted to eight countries making the sanctions less severe than anticipated, additionally removing the risk of a supply shortage according to FXTM strategist Hussein Sayed. Furthermore, Iranian press noted that the terms of the Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) with the EU will be announced soon. The SPV is the European effort to process Iran’s import and export payments. Diplomates said the details are being discussed by finance ministers, with EU Finance Ministers due to meet in Brussels on Tuesday, although the SPV was not on the agenda as of Sunday.

Gold (+0.1%) is flat and off of session highs as the yellow metal mirrors USD moves. Elsewhere, copper prices pulled back on profit taking and amid the averse risk tone.

Weekend press reports on Brexit have prompted more choppy price action, but again come with a high degree of scepticism and critique ahead of PM May’s cabinet meeting on Tuesday, while risk sentiment overall remains fragile amidst mixed messages on the US-China trade front. Turning to macro fundamentals, the October services PMI will be watched with perhaps more interest than normal given considerable divergence vs consensus for the manufacturing and construction prints last week, not to mention the fact that it has the biggest weighting for GDP.

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

5th November 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week with a negative tone after last Friday’s losses on Wall St where the Nasdaq underperformed after tech giant Apple dropped nearly 7%, while sentiment was also dampened by soft Chinese Caixin PMI data and after US-China trade hopes were tempered by pessimism from NEC’s Kudlow. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.5%) were both pressured from the open although stocks in Australia briefly recovered in tandem with the price swings in its largest weighted financial sector as participants mulled over Westpac’s flat FY profits, while focus in Japan remained on corporate updates including index heavyweight Fast Retailing which slumped following a 10% decline in same-store sales. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-2.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.0%) were negative after US administration officials downplayed prospects of an imminent resolution to the US-China trade dispute and with Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMI at the weakest since September 2017 and June 2016 respectively, while the PBoC Medium-term Lending Facility announcement and President Xi’s pledge to further open up China’s economy only helped plug losses momentarily.

STRESS TEST RESULTS

All 48 banks beat the 5.5% fully loaded capital threshold in adverse scenario, however Barclays (BARC LN) and Lloyds Banking Group (LLOY LN) were among the worst performers amongst the banks with CET1 ratios of 6.37% and 6.80% respectively amid weak growth, credit losses and Brexit uncertainly. Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) performed better than some expected with a ratio of 8.14%, while Banco BPM (BAMI IM) was the worst among Italian lenders, registering a ratio of 6.67% following a slump in the nation’s bonds amid political turmoil.  

FTSE

Rolls Royce (RR/ LN) / Airbus (AIR FP) – Emirates is moving towards a deal with Rolls Royce to power their latest A380 Airbus superjumbos; but a deal has not yet been reached. (Newswires)

IAG (IAG LN) – British Airways have been accused of providing an awful service, after over 100 passengers were delayed in the US for just under 3 days due to a technical fault. (The Guardian)

IWG (IWG LN) – The Co’s founder is planning a GBP 2.2bln break-up which may result in its property portfolio eventually being sold to outside investors. (Sky News)

UK Businesses – Over 70 business leaders have backed calls for a say on the final terms of Britain’s EU exit, warning that the EU faces a ‘blindfold or a destructive hard Brexit’ which would be bad for firms and jobs (The Independent)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Marks & Spencer (MKS LN) – Co. considered a radical plan to split into two separate businesses before concluding that the move would not generate value for shareholders. (Times)

BROKER MOVES

PADDY POWER BETFAIR (PPB LN) UPGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FORM UNDERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) –Co’s boss is to outline a 10yr plan to cut research costs by working with rivals on November 16th; which will side-line Audi as the group’s leading research hub. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 5th November 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets began the week with a negative tone following last Friday’s losses on Wall St after US-China trade hopes were tempered by pessimism from NEC’s Kudlow
  • UK PM May secured private concessions from Brussels that will keep Britain in a customs union and avoid a hard border, according to reports; later denied
  • In FX markets, the DXY was relatively flat and held on to most of Friday’s NFP-inspired rebound with EUR/USD contained below the 1.1400 handle
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK services PMI, US ISM non-mfg PMI, EZ finance ministers to discuss Italy, ECB’s de Guindos, Praet, BoC’s Poloz, US 3yr Note Auction

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week with a negative tone after last Friday’s losses on Wall St where the Nasdaq underperformed after tech giant Apple dropped nearly 7%, while sentiment was also dampened by soft Chinese Caixin PMI data and after US-China trade hopes were tempered by pessimism from NEC’s Kudlow. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.5%) were both pressured from the open although stocks in Australia briefly recovered in tandem with the price swings in its largest weighted financial sector as participants mulled over Westpac’s flat FY profits, while focus in Japan remained on corporate updates including index heavyweight Fast Retailing which slumped following a 10% decline in same-store sales. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-2.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.0%) were negative after US administration officials downplayed prospects of an imminent resolution to the US-China trade dispute and with Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMI at the weakest since September 2017 and June 2016 respectively, while the PBoC Medium-term Lending Facility announcement and President Xi’s pledge to further open up China’s economy only helped plug losses momentarily. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher as the risk averse tone spurred demand for safety. This helped prices recover from Friday’s declines which coincided with a sell-off in T-notes and a surge in US yields by the most in the month following the NFP-beat.

PBoC skipped open market operations but conducted CNY 403.5bln 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility vs. Prev. CNY 265bln with rates unchanged at 3.30%. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8976 (Prev. 6.9371)

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (Oct) 50.8 vs. Exp. 52.9 (Prev. 53.1); lowest since September 2017
Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Oct) 50.5 (Prev. 52.1); lowest since June 2016

Chinese President Xi said China pledges to open market to the world, while he added that countries must pursue open policy and oppose protectionism. Furthermore, President Xi stated that China will stimulate potential for increased imports and are to further reduce import tariffs. (Newswires)

BoJ minutes from September meeting stated that most members shared the view that the year-on-year rate of change in the CPI was likely to increase gradually toward 2% and that it is appropriate to continue easing persistently. Furthermore, the minutes noted that financial conditions are highly accommodative and that most members agreed momentum to target was intact. (Newswires)

BoJ Governor Kuroda said BoJ is aware continued loose policy impacts financial system stability and financial intermediation, while he added the BoJ must carefully watch demerits of easing and that large deflation policy is no longer the most appropriate. Kuroda also commented that when BoJ seeks to exit easy policy, the yield curve will steepen although that alone will not lift financial institutions out of structural problems, while he later reiterated there is no change in stance of reaching 2% target and that BoJ needs to continue easing persistently to the CPI target. (Newswires)


UK/EU

UK PM May secured private concessions from Brussels that will keep Britain in a customs union and avoid a hard border, while reports also noted Britain is on course for a future economic partnership deal with the EU. (Sunday Times) However, some sources noted that Downing Street had dismissed this as speculation. (Twitter) May will host a cabinet meeting on Tuesday and will reportedly tell ministers that failure to support her plans with make dissenters responsible for a no-deal Brexit. (Newswires)

UK Brexit Secretary Raab pressed UK PM May to take a hard line regarding Irish border and urged her to back plan to pull UK out of backstop plan at only 3-months notice. (Telegraph/FT)

Senior EU officials stated that UK PM May's chances of reaching an Irish border deal are '50-50' and that competing red lines between UK and EU continue to be incompatible in important areas. (Guardian)

Brexit negotiators are still attempting to overcome differences over customs, goods trade and Northern Ireland but financial services issues are all but settled, according to EU diplomats. (FT)

ECB's Rehn (Non-Voter, Dovish) said 1.6%-1.8% inflation is "to my mind" not yet below but close to 2% and suggested that a more symmetric assessment should be adopted. (Newswires)

Sources said no decision will be made on the ECB TLTRO at the December policy meeting and one source said the TLTRO would help banks to avoid a 'cliff edge' in 2020. Furthermore, another source said TLTRO only needed if policy transmission mechanism was hampered. (Newswires)


FX

In FX markets, the DXY was relatively flat and held on to most of Friday’s NFP-inspired rebound. This contained EUR/USD below the 1.1400 handle, while GBP/USD gapped higher on news UK PM May secured private concessions from Brussels that will keep Britain in a customs union and avoid a hard border, although the pair has retreated from its highs to back below the 1.3000 handle as other reports suggested this was speculation. Elsewhere, USD/JPY traded flat and was unfazed by the negative risk tone, while antipodeans were lacklustre following the disappointing Chinese trade data and with NZD also subdued by some downbeat comments regarding business confidence and potential risk to the growth outlook.
 

New Zealand Treasury monthly economic indicators stated that business confidence eased further in the September quarter but seems to have stabilized, while it added that weak confidence is a risk to 2018-2019 GDP growth expectations and global growth prospects eased amid trade frictions. (Newswires)



COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly uneventful in which WTI crude futures languished below the USD 63.00/bbl despite the US sanctions on Iranian being re-imposed overnight, as the US had also announced to provide exemptions to 8 countries, while natgas futures gapped higher by around 5% at the open on expectations of severe weather conditions with arctic air set to hit central US this week. Elsewhere, gold prices were subdued as the greenback held on to most its post-NFP gains, while copper prices pulled back on profit taking in the red metal and amid the risk averse tone.

Baker Hughes Rig Count (02/Nov): Oil rigs down 1 at 874, gas rigs unchanged at 193, total rigs down 1 at 1067. (Newswires)

US President Trump confirmed that sanctions on Iran including energy, shipping and banking will take effect on November 5th. In related news, Iraqi officials said the US is to grant Baghdad a waiver over some Iran sanctions. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea reportedly warned to resume its nuclear program if US sanctions continue, according to reports which cited the Foreign Ministry’s Institute for American Studies Director Kwon Jong Gun. (KCNA) Elsewhere, South Korea and US are reported to resume military drills ahead of nuclear discussions. (SCMP)


US

USTs sold off on Friday as yields surged by the most in the month and which saw the 30yr touch its highest since mid-2014. This followed the better than expected NFP jobs data which supported expectations for further rate hikes from the Fed and in turn saw US T-note futures (Z8) settle 17 ticks lower at 118-01+.

US President Trump said on Friday that the US is much closer to doing something on trade with China and that he will make a very good deal with China, while he added he will have dinner with Xi at the G20 summit and that if the US can open up China and make it fair, he is willing to do it. (Newswires)

White House NEC director Kudlow said he wants to keep expectations low on US - China talks and that he doesn't expect detailed trade deal from talks between Trump and Xi. Kudlow also commented that more tariffs on China are possible and Trump has not asked the cabinet to make a China trade plan, while he confirmed he hasn't seen any new proposals from China and is not as optimistic as before that a trade deal will be reached but added If talks improve then tariffs could be removed. (Newswires)

Press reports speculated that any agreement reached between President Trump and Chinese President Xi is likely to be a temporary truce instead of a significant step forward. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia stocks begin the week negative amid US-China trade pessimism and disappointing Chinese Caixin PMIs
content: Asia equity markets began the week with a negative tone after last Friday’s losses on Wall St where the Nasdaq underperformed after tech giant Apple dropped nearly 7% on product sales and outlook disappointment, while sentiment was also dampened by soft Chinese Caixin PMI data and after US-China trade hopes were tempered by pessimism from NEC’s Kudlow. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.5%) were both pressured from the open although stocks in Australia briefly recovered in tandem with the price swings in its largest weighted financial sector as participants mulled over Westpac’s flat FY profits, while focus in Japan remained on corporate updates including index heavyweight Fast Retailing which slumped following a 10% decline in same-store sales. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-2.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.0%) were negative after US administration officials downplayed prospects of an imminent resolution to the US-China trade dispute and with Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMI at the weakest since September 2017 and June 2016 respectively, while the PBoC Medium-term Lending Facility announcement and President Xi’s pledge to further open up China’s economy only helped plug losses momentarily. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher as the risk averse tone spurred demand for safety. This helped prices recover from Friday’s declines which coincided with a sell-off in T-notes and a surge in US yields by the most in the month following the NFP-beat.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia begins the week on the back foot amid pessimism regarding US-China trade and after Chinese Caixin PMIs disappoint
content:
Asia equity markets begin the week with a negative tone after last Friday’s losses on Wall St where the Nasdaq underperformed after tech giant Apple dropped nearly 7% on product sales and outlook disappointment, while sentiment is also dampened by soft Chinese Caixin PMI data and after US-China trade hopes were tempered by pessimism from NEC Director Kudlow. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 both opened lower although stocks in Australia briefly recovered in tandem with the price swings in its largest weighted financial sector as participants mulled over Westpac’s flat FY profits, while focus in Japan remained on corporate updates including index heavyweight Fast Retailing which slumped following a 10% decline in same-store sales. Elsewhere, Hang Seng and Shanghai Comp. are negative after US administration officials downplayed prospects of an imminent resolution to the US-China trade dispute and after Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMI printed the weakest since September 2017 and June 2016 respectively, while the PBoC Medium-term Lending Facility announcement and President Xi’s pledge to further open up China’s economy only provided minimal support to the region.

In FX markets, the DXY is relatively flat and holds on to most of Friday’s NFP-inspired rebound in which the stronger than forecast US jobs data bolstered expectations for further rate hikes from the Fed, which has contained EUR/USD below the 1.1400 handle. GBP/USD gapped higher on news UK PM May secured private concessions from Brussels that will keep Britain in a customs union and avoid a hard border, although the pair is off its highs and back below the 1.3000 handle as other reports suggested this was speculation. Elsewhere, USD/JPY trades flat despite the negative risk tone, while antipodeans are lacklustre following the disappointing Chinese trade data and with NZD also subdued by some downbeat comments regarding business confidence and potential risk to the growth outlook.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat although prices have recovered from some of Friday’s pressure which was in tandem with the sell-off in T-notes post NFP-beat, which saw yields surge by the most in the month and pushed the US 30yr yield to its highest since mid-2014.
